adjectives.description: suss (comparative more suss, superlative most suss)

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand, US, colloquial) Suspicious.
examples: ‘Yes – OK, OK. Try not to struggle, Tracey. It just makes you look even more suss.’

entries.meaning: (UK) Suspicious behaviour; the act of loitering with intent.

verbs.description: suss (third-person singular simple present susses, present participle sussing, simple past and past participle sussed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, obsolete) To arrest for suspicious behaviour.

description: From suspect; originally suss out (“to investigate”).

examples: ‘I′m surprised at you, Danny Weston! I thought you had a bit more suss than this. I never thought you were capable of something so ... silly.’

verbs.description: suss (third-person singular simple present susses, present participle sussing, simple past and past participle sussed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, Australia, New Zealand, often with "out") To discover, infer or figure out.
examples: This David did without the crook knowing he had been sussed out. […] When David returned home after sussing this new crook, he made sure one or two key people were informed about his true nature, and they were all then further protected.

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK, Australia, New Zealand) To study or size up, to check out (examine).
